procedure: Left Total Knee Revision Arthroplasty (single-component revision)
Application of negative pressure wound therapy, incisional wound vac (PREVENA)
Modular exchange/revision of the polyethylene with retention of other implants
extracted_info.summary: 60-year-old female with acute hematogenous infection of left total knee replacement performed in June 2025. Patient has history of Charcot foot arthropathy with foot ulcerations and infections. Recently developed acute onset of left knee pain and severe swelling 4 days ago. Knee aspiration showed inflammatory markers consistent with acute infection. Patient also has active foot ulcer infections and UTI as possible hematogenous sources.
diagnosis: Acute hematogenous infection of left total knee
tests: Gram Stain: positive for GPC in pairs
reports: XR Knee 2V Left (11/14/2025): Joint effusion present, total knee arthroplasty in expected position, no fracture demonstrated
allergies: Tape [Adhesive Tape-Silicones] (redness at the site of tape)
extracted_info.risk_assessment: Patient informed of risks including deep venous thrombosis, infection, nerve or blood vessel injury, ligament injury, fracture, incomplete resolution of pain, continued deformity, loss of range of motion and stiffness, and complications associated with anesthesia

procedure: Left Total Knee Revision Arthroplasty (single-component revision)
Application of negative pressure wound therapy, incisional wound vac (PREVENA)
extracted_info.summary: 60-year-old female with acute hematogenous periprosthetic infection of left knee who underwent left total knee revision arthroplasty (single-component revision) with polyethylene exchange. Patient had a history of left total knee replacement in June 2025 and developed acute knee pain and swelling 4 days prior to this procedure, with aspiration confirming infection. The procedure included extensive debridement, synovectomy, and irrigation, with implantation of a 13mm medial congruent PE liner and application of an incisional wound vac.

full_source.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Primary and secondary tumors of the proximal femur (Evidence: pg no: 24, L837)
Hip fracture or complications including malunion, nonunion or failed prior fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L838)
Failed previous hip fracture fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L839)
Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) with unresponsive severe pain (Evidence: pg no: 24, L840)
Revision of hip arthrodesis (Evidence: pg no: 24, L841)
Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L846)
Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L848-L849)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

exclusions: Indications for total hip arthroplasty other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, acetabular and proximal femoral prosthetic replacement (total hip arthroplasty), with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L973-L974)

full_source.notes: All arthroplasty and acetabuloplasty/resection arthroplasty procedures are inclusive of synovectomy, removal of osteophytes, removal of loose bodies, manipulation of the hip, and release or repair of structures to gain entrance to the hip joint. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L749-L751)

full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. This procedure is typically utilized when there is concomitant rotator cuff disease. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178-L180)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L846)
Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L848-L849)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

exclusions: Indications for total hip arthroplasty other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, acetabular and proximal femoral prosthetic replacement (total hip arthroplasty), with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L973-L974)

full_source.notes: All arthroplasty and acetabuloplasty/resection arthroplasty procedures are inclusive of synovectomy, removal of osteophytes, removal of loose bodies, manipulation of the hip, and release or repair of structures to gain entrance to the hip joint. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L749-L751)

full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. This procedure is typically utilized when there is concomitant rotator cuff disease. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178-L180)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 7, L181-L183)

documentation: Reconstruction after a tumor resection (Evidence: pg no: 10, L302)

Shoulder fracture that is not repairable or cannot be reconstructed with other techniques (Evidence: pg no: 10, L307)
Deficient rotator cuff with limited ability to actively flex the upper extremity to 90 degrees against gravity (Evidence: pg no: 10, L310-L311)

full_source.notes: Considered medically necessary for ANY of the listed indications when associated with pain and functional impairment. (Evidence: pg no: 10, L301)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

11/17/25, 8:58 AM Crawford, Melissa Lynn (MR # MR227404) DOB: 05/30/1965

H&P by Choo, Kevin, MD filed on 11/15/2025 3:20 PM.

Author: Choo, Kevin, MD Service: Orthopedics Author Type: Physician
Date of Service: 11/15/2025 Filed: 11/15/2025 3:20 PM Status: Signed
Editor: Choo, Kevin, MD (Physician)

HPI: The patient is a 60 y.o. female with history of Left total knee replacement. The patient did well and was
recovering quickly from her left knee replacement performed in June 2025.

Separately, she has a history of lower extremity neuropathy leading to Charcot feet. She has had numerous foot
procedures to correct midfoot deformities

Due to her Charcot foot arthropathy she has been dealing with ulcerations and foot infections over the years.
Recently, they had been well managed prior to the knee replacement.

More recently, she began to have worsening of her foot issues; followed by Dr Pao and wound care; she had
infection and purulence, which was cultured and she was placed on antibiotics recently. Separately, she also had
been on antibiotics for a UTI.

4 days ago she had acute onset of left knee pain and severe swelling. Prior to this she was doing well with the knee
replacement surgery. This was progressive and painful and she had a large effusion. She was sent to the GH ED
yesterday where she had elevated inflammatory markers, the knee was aspirated and was consistent with acute
infection with a highly inflammatory white blood cell count, and there was a positive culture.

She was admitted and IV antibiotics were initiated after the organism was identified. Dr Rossi from ID was consulted.
ROS: As above.

Clinical History:

The patient is a 60 y.o. female with history of Left total Knee replacement. The patient did well and was recovering
quickly from her left knee replacement performed in June 2025.

Separately, she has a history of lower extremity neuropathy leading to Charcot feet. She has had numerous foot
procedures to correct midfoot deformities

Due to her Charcot foot arthropathy she has been dealing with ulcerations and foot infections over the years.
Recently, they had been well managed prior to the knee replacement.

More recently, she began to have worsening of her foot issues; followed by Dr Pao and wound care; she had
infection and purulence, which was cultured and she was placed on antibiotics recently. Separately, she also had
been on antibiotics for a UTI.

4 days ago she had acute onset of left knee pain and severe swelling. Prior to this she was doing well with the knee
replacement surgery. This was progressive and painful and she had a large effusion. She was sent to the GH ED
yesterday where she had elevated inflammatory markers, the knee was aspirated and was consistent with acute
infection with a highly inflammatory white blood cell count, and there was a positive culture.

Crawford, Melissa Lynn (MRN MR227404) Printed by Stagno, Cesarina [767] at 11/17/2025 8:58 AM

11/17/25, 8:58 AM Crawford, Melissa Lynn (MR # MR227404) DOB: 05/30/1965
She was admitted and IV antibiotics were initiated after the organism was identified. Dr Rossi from ID was consulted.

After careful discussion of the risks and benefits of the surgery, including the potential complications of deep venous
thrombosis, infection, nerve or blood vessel injury, ligament injury, fracture, incomplete resolution of pain, continued
deformity, loss of range of motion and stiffness, and the complications associated with anesthesia, the patient has
decided that they would like to proceed with revision left knee replacement. Due to acute hematogenous nature of
the infection, we determined that modular exchange/revision of the polyethylene would be appropriate with retention
of the other implants.

Description of procedure:

The patient was met in the preoperative area, and again the associated risks of the surgery were discussed with the
patient. Informed consent was obtained. The operative site was marked. The patient was transferred to the operating
room. A spinal anesthetic was performed prior to the procedure. The patient received preoperative antibiotics within
30 minutes prior to the incision, and tranexamic acid intravenously. Tranexamic acid was also given at the end of the
case. Prior to incision a surgical time out was performed to confirm patient identification, and laterality.

Prior to the incision, we repeated aspiration under sterile conditions. 50cc of purulent fluid was aspirated and sent for
culture.

A longitudinal incision was made, centered over the anterior aspect of the knee. Soft tissue was dissected sharply
down to the extensor mechanism. A medial parapatellar arthrotomy was performed to expose the knee joint.

Soft tissue was elevated off the proximal medial tibia for exposure. Infrapatellar fat pad was excised. The patella was
subluxed laterally.

Swabs were taken and sent for microbiology.

Complete synovectomy was performed using electrocautery, curette, cobb and rongeur. We were careful to remove
synovium from the lateral gutters, supra patellar pouch, and the posterior capsule.

Using an osteotome and forcep, we were able to remove the tibial polyethylene without disrupting the tibial
component fixation. We then probed the implant/cement/bone interfaces of the femur, tibia and patellar button--
which were stable.

Full mechanical debridement undertaken throughout the joint including rongeur, curette, and bovie.

Following the synovectomy, we then performed mechanical disruption of biofilm with sponges, scrub brushes and
pulsatile lavage. A series of anti microbial fluids were irrigated through the knee including NS with Ancef, Irrisept,
Bactisure, and Surgiphor (betadine). Soft and hard brushes used to disrupt any potential biofilm on the implants.

We then placed a sterile cover on the knee and removed all dirty drapes gowns and gloves.
An entirely sterile new setup was utilized. All surgical staff re-prepped and draped in order to ensure sterility.

We then repeated our debridement and then repeated the full irrigation protocol. In total, approximtely 20L of fluid
was irrigated through the knee.

We then trialed and implanted the appropriate tibial polyethylene. The knee was taken through a full range of motion,
with excellent extension, flexion, and coronal plane balance. A 13mm medial congruent PE liner was implanted.

2g of Ancef and 2g of vancomycin powder was then placed into the deep wound.

At this point we began our closure. The arthrotomy was then closed with monofilament barbed suture; followed by
monofilament deep fatty layer closure, followed by a running #2 PDO barbed suture for the superficial tissues.
Staples were utilized for skin closure. Due to concern for poor wound healing, an incisional wound vac (PICO) was
utilized to accelerate skin healing and reduce risk for infection. The tourniquet was deflated. The patient was
transferred to the recovery room in stable condition.

Post-operative Plan:

The patient be allowed to weight-bear as tolerated.

They will receive post-operative antibiotics and be started on DVT prophylaxis.

Follow up pre and intra-operative cultures

Prevena wound vac x 7 days

Staples out in 14 days

They will be discharged home from the hospital when they are comfortable and have met all PT goals and antibiotic
plan is finalized.

Kevin Choo, MD

tmpsrb2noof.pdf.summary: 60-year-old female with acute hematogenous infection of left total knee replacement performed in June 2025. Patient has history of Charcot foot arthropathy with foot ulcerations and infections. Recently developed acute onset of left knee pain and severe swelling 4 days ago. Knee aspiration showed inflammatory markers consistent with acute infection. Patient also has active foot ulcer infections and UTI as possible hematogenous sources.
